div.p:
8. IV:30.Mr Sampson, a Member of Congress from Massachusetts called here this morning with his brother, and Mr Scott the Delegate from the Missouri Territory. I paid visits to Mr James Barbour the President of the Senate— Mr Mason of Boston and General Smith of Baltimore, at Dowson’s— To Messrs.Lyman, Sergeant Storrs, Street and Van Rensselaer at Miss Hyer’s, and to Messrs.D. P. Cook and Scott at Davis’s— Also to Major Burd of the army. I went into the Hall’s of the House of Representatives which was in Session, and of the Senate which had just adjourned. At One O’Clock I attended at the President’s, and presented Mr La Serna, the Spanish Charge d’Affaires— Mr Antrobus afterwards came with Sir Charles Saxton, whom he presented to the President. After they were gone the President asked me, whether I had seen Mr Torres, or Mr Hyde de Neuville since the appearance of the Message; and whether they had spoken of it. I had not seen the French Minister, and although I met Mr Torres yesterday at dinner, he said nothing to me of the Message. The President appeared to be uneasy on the subject of South-America, and said he understood Mr Clay had given notice that he intended to bring forward again in the house the question for the acknowledgment of Buenos-Ayres— And excepting that he said he did not know that there was anything upon which a systematic and organized effort against the Administration could be made in Congress— I observed that the great battery opened upon the Administration at the Session before last, was South-America. That of the last Session was the Seminole War— It was perhaps not possible to foretell where the enemies of the administration would think they could discern its weak side, to direct their attack against it. I thought the South-American question was too much worn out; and although Mr Clay would certainly bring it up
again, there would be members enough in the house, able and willing to maintain the argument against him, and I questioned whether he could now get a stronger final vote than he had obtained two years ago, on that topic— The President replied that last year and the year before, Pazos and Clemente, and Aguirre had been used as tools against the Administration; the course they had taken was in concert with and dictated by Clay— He had suspected so at the time, but had lately received information strongly confirming the suspicion— In fact Torres himself had told him as much; and assured him that the authority upon which he was acting, was founded on principles entirely different. His instructions were to press nothing upon this Government contrary to its wishes or its policy; and he should act accordingly— I observed that Mr Torres had made the same professions to me; but so had De Forest last Winter, and yet had been one of the most troublesome of the South American Agents— I added that there would be before the Congress, all the monied embarrassments of the Country— The affairs of the Bank—the Manufacturing claims, and the Missouri Slave question, which might excite ardent debates— He said the Executive had nothing to do with either of them; which is true so far, that the Executive is not yet at issue upon either of them— If he ultimately escapes them all, he will be more fortunate than I anticipate— I said I had received a Letter from Mr John Pope of Kentucky, in which without much further explanation he had written “let the administration be prepared to be attacked about the Yellow Stone expedition”; and I heard here, and even in Boston obscure intimations of complaint against that expectation, and surmises against Coll. Richard M. Johnson, and his brother, who are the contractors for supplies to the troops employed upon it. The honesty of the Johnson’s is deeply implicated, and rumours are afloat that advances have been made to them by the Government, which will eventuate in a loss of public money. And that the whole Estate of the late Pay-master General Robert Brent was in jeopardy for such advances which cannot be accounted for according to Law— He said that Mr Daniel Brent after the death of his brother Robert had come to him, and mentioned that the Estate was made responsible for certain advances made during the late War, by an order from him Mr Monroe, while he was acting Secretary at War, of which he had no recollection whatever;—but that he did not suppose that those advances had been made to Coll. Johnson— He had heard that Mr Clay had censured the cost of the Yellow-Stone expedition; but there was no measure of the Administration which had given so general satisfaction in the Western Country as that— While he was in Kentucky, a paper expressing the highest approbation of it, and recommending earnestly the Johnson’s as contractors for it was presented to him, signed by Governor Shelby, by General Jackson as an individual, and by Coll. Morrison and many others persons of the highest character and consideration— And as to the advances made, Mr Calhoun declares that the Government are amply secured against loss— But Mr Mason, brother of him who was killed here last winter in a duel, and who is now Marshal of Kentucky told the President that Mr Clay was desirous of withdrawing from his situation here, by being elected Governor of Kentucky; and his friends were confident of his success, if Coll. Richard M. Johnson, who would be his competitor, should withdraw from the contest— Johnson had been applied to for that purpose by some of Clay’s friends; but after consulting some friends of his own had declined to withdraw— If Clay therefore should make a formal attack upon the Yellow-Stone expedition, its object probably be to cripple Johnson’s character, so that he might not be in his way as a Candidate for the Governors Office. This may be—but I doubt much of Clay’s wish to be Governor of Kentucky at present— I also doubt whether he will make any public complaint about the Yellow-Stone expedition— I spoke to the President as to the time when Mr John Graham’s Salary should commence, upon which he came to no final determination; and read him a draft of an answer to Antrobus, on the case of the Crooks’s claim, which he approved— He directed me also to see Major W. Jackson, and propose to him to go upon this agency to Chili— Mr S. Parkman of Boston, called at my Office today at one O’Clock just as I was going to the President’s— I could not then see him—and he could not call again. Cardelli was here this Evening.

9. VI:30. There came to the Office a Mr Kenrick, inventor of a machine for removing the Bars of Rivers by deepening the Water— He brought a drawing and a model of the machine; which is a complicated plough, to be drawn by a Steam boat— He supposes that by breaking up the ground at the bottom of the river; where the current is strong it will carry away the clods and deepen the channel to any desired extent— He brought with him several recommendatory certificates, and I had sometime since a Letter from Governor Brooks recommending him. His object is to petition Congress to supply funds necessary for making the experiment; and he asked me to apply to the President for permission to exhibit his model, and explain his plan to him— The President himself called at the Office, to give some directions concerning the agent who is going to the Coast of Africa to receive the Africans who are to be sent there. To my great surprize I found that he was to be furnished with a credit of twenty thousand Dollars upon the House of Barings in London to be expended for the support of blacks in Africa, who are to be sent there from the United States— I asked the President if it was clear that the Executive was authorised to incur this expence by the Act of the last Session— He thought so; but said he would have a general consultation of the administration upon it, at his house at twelve O’Clock to-morrow— He also spoke of instructing Mr Gallatin to apply to the French Government soliciting their interposition with Spain to induce the ratification of the Treaty, without compelling us to do Justice to ourselves— I said I thought it would be better to press this upon Mr de Neuville here, than to make it a subject of direct instruction to Mr Gallatin. By urging it through the French Minister here, the motives to be suggested will be of a general nature; applying as much to the interests of France, as to those of this Union— But a direct instruction to Mr Gallatin to apply to the French Government might have the appearance of soliciting their interposition— I had already impressed upon Mr. De Neuville the importance of France’s using all her influence with Spain for the preservation of Peace; and as soon as Congress shall have acted on the subject. I proposed to instruct Mr Gallatin as well as Mr Forsyth, & Mr Rush to make known the intentions of this Government, in the course they pursue— I spoke to the President of the necessity of fixing upon some person as a Minister to Russia instead of Mr Campbell, who if not already on his way to return, will come home in the Spring— He said he had not thought of anyone, but observed that at the time of the appointment of Mr Campbell, General Harrison had been mentioned— I named Mr Middleton, as a person peculiarly fitted for this Mission, as being from a state the inhabitants of which had suffered most by the loss of Slaves; and as being by his great fortune able to bear the expence of residing as a Public Minister, without starving upon the Salary allowed— The President said he did not know but Mr Middleton would be as good an appointment as could be made, and asked if he would accept—which I did not know— He said that in South Carolina there was also Mr Poinsett— From all this I conclude that Mr Middleton is quite out of the question— Mrs Adams had this Evening a party at tea of nearly a hundred persons, about one third of which were Ladies. Mr de Neuville told me, he was entirely satisfied with the President’s Message— Poletica spoke to me of the appointment of a Minister to Russia, and said that Mr Poinsett would be extremely acceptable to the Emperor— This coincidence shews that there has already been intriguing with the President for this appointment— Mr Francis Parkman the Clergyman of Boston was at my Office this day, and at the Evening party.

10. VII:Mr de Mun came to my Office this Morning with a Note from the French Minister Hyde de Neuville expressing surprize and regret at learning this morning that his notes connected with the Florida Negotiation were to be published with the documents annexed to the message. His objection however is only to a passage in my Observations of 24. July last addressed to him, in which he was reminded of having said to me while we were discussing the 8th. Article of the Florida Treaty that Onis had a special motive for having it so drawn as to annul the grants, for the vindication of his character from aspersions in our newspapers which had asserted that he had a personal interest in them— When I saw Mr de Neuville at New-York, he objected to a particular expression that I had used in the Note of 24. July, importing that he had told me Onis made it a point of honour to annul the grants—he had not used those words; but he had very distinctly conveyed the idea— However
as de Neuville was extremely unwilling to have the remark itself go to the Public, and as he hinged his objection upon the words Point of honour, the whole passage was omitted in the copy of the observations communicated to Congress—which I desired Mr de Mun to tell him— There was a Cabinet Meeting at the President’s at Noon. Messrs.Crawford, Thompson and Wirt, present. The Act of Congress against the Slave trade of the last Session, and the questions of Construction arising from it were under consideration. The Colonization Society are indefatigable in their efforts to get hold of the funds appropriated by that act; and having got the ear of the President, and Crawford for purposes of his own being one of them, they have already got their fingers into the purse; the Government is to pay 1500 dollars for half the freight of a vessel they are about sending to Africa— Their Colony is to be formed at the Island of Sherbro on the Coast of Guinea, about five degrees North of the Line; so perfect a desert, that they are to send out even the timber to build the huts in which their Colonists are to dwell. And with all the multitudes of their members and auxiliary Societies, and newspaper puff’s, they have no funds, and they are ravenous as Panthers for the appropriation of 100000 dollars of the last Session. Crawford’s construction of the Law, would deliver up to them the whole of it, without reserve, though he professes to be very much upon his guard against them, and to have no belief in their success— This agent with a discretionary credit of twenty thousand dollars upon London is a clear forecast of what is to follow— Wirt in the first instance construed the Law, still more strictly than I did— He was brought over, by the arguments of Crawford, who is ready to make a Colony, out of the Law of the last Session; and Mr Thompson, who thinks the law very loosely worded and that it ought to be explained, still thinks it will admit of a liberal construction, to give effect to the President’s power of spending the money. Crawford urges the most liberal construction, because the object of the act is beneficent, and affects no rights. I objected that there was no authority given by the Law to spend money to maintain the blacks in Africa at all. That if the authority is to be assumed constructively I see no limit to it but the amount of the appropriation, which will be soon expended if we are to maintain the Colony, and which will plunge us deep enough, into the plan to bind the honour of the Nation to further appropriations. The money is to be entrusted to the discretion of an Agent under little responsibility; and from the tendency of all such expenditures, to swell, exemplified in the application of similar funds to the relief of distressed American Seamen, and in the army pensioner Law, this would soon become a drain upon the Nation— Then would come complaints of extravagance and waste— Then enquiries in Congress how the money has been spent, and then by what authority. Then too would come the temper, not so well disposed to construe the law liberally, or to regard it as exclusively beneficent— And the time for the Executive to think of all this is now— The President finally concluded to pay half the freight of this ship now, and then to send a Message to Congress, informing them how the Law has been understood and acted upon; and then if Congress do nothing to explain the Law, it will give the function of their tacit assent to the liberal construction, and the discretionary expenditure— There was little time for doing any thing at the Meeting, at my Office— Mr Charles Pinckney, a member of the House of Representatives from South-Carolina paid me a visit this Morning; and Messrs.Jones and Cocke, Members from Tennessee this Evening— Pinckney has an unaccountable fancy that he saw me in the year 1784 at New-York; and that I was then going with Colonel Humphreys to Europe— Cocke is a Son of John Cocke, with whom I sat two or three years in the Senate.

11. VII: Morning visits from Genl. S. Smith of Baltimore, Mr Simkins, a member of the House of Representatives from South Carolina, Quarles from Kentucky, Sloane from Ohio, and Woodbridge Delegate from the Territory of Michigan— At the Office a succession of visitors consumed the day— Levitt Harris came yesterday and asked for two of the papers, which he had sent here with the defence of his character against the charges of Hurd and J. D. Lewis, accusing him of corrupt practices in his Office of Consul at St. Petersburg; for which he had applied to the President, who had referred him to me. Mr Brent was gone when Harris came yesterday, and was absent from the Office all this day— Harris came again this day, and asked for all the papers of his case, with a promise to return them, which I accordingly gave him. W. Lee came with a Mr Rice, an Agent
for certain claims upon the black king, Henry of Haÿti, for which two agents have been sent to Saint-Domingo— Mr Rice comes now to present a petition for the claimants to Congress which I informed some of them at Boston (See Journal of 22. September last) was the only authority competent to afford them a remedy at this time—though I gave them no encouragement to expect that Congress would apply it: nothing less than a blockade of Christophes Ports, being adequate to the purpose. Mr Torres came to make the communication that General Arismendi had been appointed Vice-President of the Government of Venezuela, in the place of Mr Zea: and to inform me that he was going to Philadelphia, and New-York to endeavour to procure arms of which they were in great want; and if they should not succeed he should come back and make application for them to the Government of the United States— He declared himself highly gratified with the President’s Message, and particularly with the part relating to South America. He said that Dr Forsyth would go with him—that he is not in the service of the Government of Venezuela; but goes with him merely as a friend to assist him if his health, which is infirm should require it— Mr Cutting came to ask a decision, upon a claim of additional allowance for service rendered in Algerine negotiation, twenty-five years ago— The account was then settled, and left a balance of upwards of 400 dollars due from him to the United States— He wishes to make a balance due to him by this supplementary claim to an allowance for returning home to the United States, though he actually did not return. In the year 1814 Mr Monroe being Secretary of State wrote a Letter to the Auditor, recommending that the allowance should be made. The Auditor Harrison, offered to make an allowance; such as he thought usual in other like cases; but it did not cover the whole balance, and Cutting declined taking it. He now calls upon me for a decision; I told him I could only refer it to the fifth Auditor, Mr Pleasonton— Cutting who has been the last ten years a Clerk in the War Department complains bitterly of the insufficiency of his Salary, upon which he is about presenting a memorial to Congress— Young Brown came again to ask me to speak in his favour to Coll Freeman for a vacant Clerkship in his Office— It was six O’Clock when I came home to dinner. Dr Forsyth was here this Evening, and in a manner quite intelligible gave me to understand that he would be glad to obtain the appointment of agent of the United States in Venezuela— Mr Torres had mentioned this morning that he was charged to express the wish that such an agent, or a Consul might be appointed; and read me an extract of a Letter from Dr Roscio, referring to the appointment of a Mr Lowrie as Consul at Caraccas in 1810. and of a Mr Scott as agent in 1811.— Evening much wasted.

12. V:45. Attended with Charles at the Hall of the House of Representatives in the Capitol; and heard a Sermon from Mr Post the chaplain this year chosen by the Senate— He is a presbyterian and preaches extempore, with an uninterrupted flow of words, and not much circulation of thought. He had the peculiar doctrines of his sect, quite at his command, and without being absolutely dull, was not very animated in his manner of delivery. After church, I paid visits—to Mr Baldwin and Coll. Bomford; with whom I had very short parley, before old Captain Consul O’Brien hove in sight— I left him with them; and went to Crawford’s at Georgetown, and saw Mr C. Pinckney—full of his paper Currency project— I left Cards there for Mr. and Mrs Otis and Mr William Foster— Then returned; stopped O’Neals and left Cards for Mr Rhea of Tennessee and Mr Archer; after which I called upon Dr Lovell, whom I found at home with his family. The rest of the day at home.

13. VI:30.Mr Julius Forrest, from Upper Marlborough was here, to propose from a Mr Oden, a transfer of my Stock in the Planter’s Bank of Prince George’s County for an equal amount of Stock in the Bank of the Metropolis, to which I consented, and the necessary papers were passed for making the transfers. I called at Mr Calhoun’s, to consult him, and ask some information from the War Department, for the draft of an Answer to a Letter yesterday received from Mr Lowndes—Chairman of the Committee of foreign Relations— We were interrupted by a succession of visitors— Dr. Tucker the Treasurer, and Mr Tucker a member of the House from Virginia, Major Jackson, Mr James Parker, and Mr Kinsley, members from Maine and twoEdwards’s, Clerk in the War Department, followed by Coll. Brooke, came in, till I found I must postpone most of the conversation I had proposed to have with Calhoun to another day. He promised to give
me in a day or two from his Department the information required by the Committee. As Mr Gallatin has asked to be recalled and proposes to return to the United States next Spring, I asked Calhoun whether he would accept the Mission to France— He said it would suit him in every respect but the expence. He could not afford it. I said it was not easy to reply to that objection, the Salaries of our Ministers abroad being so excessively inadequate to their necessary expences that they could not remain long in Europe without drawing upon their private resources— But as I expected more from him than from any other man living, to the benefit of the public service of this Nation, I wished from purely public motives that he could go and spend some time in Europe, because I was convinced it would much enlarge his sphere of usefulness, by familiarizing him with facts and a description of knowledge, which could in no other way be acquired— He said he was well aware that a long and familiar practical acquaintance with Europe, was indispensable to complete the Education of an American Statesman; and regretted that his Fortune would not bear the cost of it. We had not time to continue the discussion, but I told him I should speak to him about it again. As I was going to my Office I stopped at the Bank of the Metropolis, and made some enquiries as to the Condition of their Stock; from the result of which, though not entirely satisfied I accepted the proposal of transfer made by Mr. J. Forrest— At the Office, I had several visitors— Mr Kendrick, the inventor of the machine for removing Bars from Rivers. I had not thought of mentioning to the President his wish to exhibit his model, and explain his machine to him. I asked him to call again. Mr Forrest came twice; first to finish the arrangement for the mutual transfer of Planter’s Bank Stock for that of the Bank of the Metropolis; and then with G. Thomas the Clerk at the Bank to complete the transfer. He produced a Letter from B. Oden to authorise the transfer of so much of the Stock of the Bank of the Metropolis to me, and I gave him an authority, on that transfer’s being made to transfer my Planters Bank Stock to B. Oden— Mr Lomonossof the Secretary of the Russian Legation came with a Packet from Poletica to Pozzo di Borgo, to be forwarded. Lomonosof is just recovering from a severe fever, which has confined him several weeks at Baltimore— Mr Lowndes came to enquire for a report made to the old Congress, in the year 1785 by Mr Jay, relative to the right of navigating the Mississippi river— The Clerk who keeps the Book of Records was gone, and Mr Lowndes is to call again tomorrow. I read to him the draft of an answer I had made to his Letter as Chairman of the Committee of Foreign Relations— I asked him if despatches containing confidential communications, of a nature not to be made public, could safely be made to the Committee— He said that John Randolph was a member of the Committee; and his principle being that all injunctions of secrecy must give way to the public interest, a secret communicated to him, must be at the mercy of his discretion; to be divulged whenever in his judgment the public interest requires it— The President he added had some experience of Randolph’s application of this principle, and could judge how far consistently with it confidential communications could be safely made to the Committee. I took the draft to the President’s, and the despatches from Mr Gallatin and Mr Fromentin which I intended to have sent to the Committee. On my reading Gallatin’s Letters, the President said they must not be sent to the Committee— He did not suspect Randolph of intentional treachery; but he was so indiscreet, and suffered himself to be so entirely governed by his passions that the result was the same— He kept Gallatin’s Letters and said he would look them over, and direct whether extracts from them could be given— Mr Pedersen the Danish Minister was also at the Office, and spoke of the old affair of the Brig Hendrick— Cardelli was here this Evening.

14. VI:15. I returned the visits of several Members of Congress— At the Office, Mr Burrill, a Senator from Rhode Island Mr Buck, the Consul General from Hamburg, and Mr Lowndes, came in succession— Mr Burrill, brought a memorial from several claimants upon the Swedish Government for indemnity on account of the seizure of a number of vessels and Cargoes, at Stralsund in the year 1810— The memorial was addressed to the President, but I told Burrill that Negotiation had been exhausted upon this subject, and that the Memorialists had better apply to Congress.— I mentioned to him what had been done, by Mr Russell, and Mr Hughes; he asked if there would be any objection to his moving in Senate for copies of the Correspondence— I said none except that the Correspondence had not been altogether temperate on our
part, and that while we were at swords points with Spain, it might not be altogether politic to shew ourselves to all the world at pin’s points with other Nations. He took back the Memorial, and said he should advise the claimants to petition to Congress. Mr Buck came upon the claim of the owners of the Cargo of the Brig Hendrick who were Hamburgers— This affair was debated over in Congress, I believe every Session that I was there; from 1803 to 1808. and is likely to continue there as long as a Chancery suit does in England— Mr Buck is to bring me tomorrow, the pamphlet from the Documents of Congress in 1804—or 5— Mr Lowndes came again to read Mr Jay’s Report in the Secret Journals of the Old Congress; and the volume containing it, was taken to his lodgings.— I received a note from the President, advising that neither the despatches from Mr Gallatin, nor extracts from them should be sent to the Committee. Mr Lowndes appears to be of opinion that Congress will do nothing upon Spanish Affairs till towards the close of the Session— Mrs Adams had invited an evening party for this day; but she was taken so ill with a sick head-ache and successive faintings, that she was confined to her bed— The only Ladies who came to the party were Madame de Neuville and Mrs Gresham, and Mrs Colvin— There were about sixty gentlemen, chiefly members of Congress— Mrs Smith received the Ladies— Dr Huntt was here.

15. VI: I called at Mr Calhoun’s this Morning, but did not find him at home— I was occupied almost the whole time of Office hours, in examining over again the Accounts for contingent expences of the Department— The looseness with which the business was heretofore transacted is such that a new mode of accountability for the expenditures is at once difficult to introduce and indispensable— Mr Buck called, and left the pamphlet relating to the case of the Brig Hendrick— I received two Letters from Mr Lowndes as Chairman of the Committee of the House of Representatives, and a Resolution of the House, directing a Report upon Weights and Measures— Called at the President’s, but he was at dinner, and I did not see him— I attended this Evening Mrs Monroe’s first Drawing Room for the Season— It was very thinly attended—only four or five Ladies— Among the Company was Mr John Lowell, whom I introduced to the President, and whom I invited to dine with me to-morrow, but he was engaged. Mr Edwards the Senator from Illinois, took a seat with me to come home— Mrs Adams was this day better, but confined to her chamber, and great part of the day to her bed— Mrs Smith was here.

16. V: I made a draft for an answer to the confidential question of the Committee of foreign Relations, and brought up my arrears of Journal, an arduous and ever recurring task— Major Jackson called this morning, as I had last Evening requested, and by the President’s direction I proposed to him to go as the Agent of this Government to Chile; he said he would consult his family, and soon give me his answer— Mr John Lowell also called upon me, and Mr James Greenleaf to propose to sell me some City Lots, which however does not at present suit my views. I called upon Mr Calhoun, and read to him the answer to the Committee’s Question— I could have scarcely any conversation with him upon other subjects as we were continually interrupted by other visitors— Coll. Bomford, and the Surgeon General Lovell were with him when I went in— He gave me a very high character of Lovell after he went away— I was a very short time at the Office, but called at the President’s and took his directions upon various subjects. He approved the draft of an answer to the Question of the Committee; and shewed me the Message he had prepared upon the Slave-trade Act of the last Session— It stated rather indistinctly the Construction given to the Act, and the authority to spend money to the amount of twenty five thousand dollars, in Africa, to support the exported Slaves there; and then left Congress to decide whether this was or was not the correct construction of the Act— If not, Congress are to pass an explanatory or amendatory Act— I objected that this form of the Message would leave no alternative to members friendly to the administration, but to approve the Construction, or to appear in opposition to the Construction of the President, and to the Administration— He said he would add a paragraph saying that the whole is still under the Consideration of Congress, and subject to their controul. The President also spoke to me, on the subject of the etiquette of visits— It would seem that some of the Senators have been to him to complain that the Secretary of State refuses to pay them the first visit— He mentioned it with much delicacy, but observed that it occasioned uneasiness, heart burnings, and severe criticism— He wished therefore that the heads of Departments would meet and agree upon some rule which they should all observe, for visiting, as one of the great difficulties arose, from different persons following different practices— I told the President what my own practice had been: the deputation that came to me two years ago, from the Senators; my answer to them then and the rules since observed by myself and my wife— I said I would with pleasure consult the other heads of Departments, and abide by such rules as a majority of them should agree to— He desired it might be done as soon as possible— We had this day Company to dinner— Mr and Mrs Hyde de Neuville, Mr Poletica, Mr and Mrs
Greuhm, Commodore and Mrs Rogers, Mr. Antrobus, Viscount Quabeck, Baron Stackelberg, Mr La Serna, Mr Sergeant, Coll. Aspinwall and Major Jackson—and Mr Pedersen— The party broke up about nine in the Evening.

17. VI:30.Mr Upham, a member of Congress from New-Hampshire, and Mr Ringgold and Dr Kent, members from Maryland called upon me this Morning— I stopped at Mr Calhoun’s and told him of the President’s wish that the Heads Of Departments should meet and agree upon some uniform rule with respect to visits— Calhoun agreed to meet on Monday— I also called at the Treasury Office, but Mr Crawford was not there; and at Mr Wirt’s— I found him; and he wishes that the meeting may be at the President’s— To this the President upon whom I called, assented— Mr Buck the Consul from Hamburg came, and again urged that the President should recommend the claim of the owners of the Cargo of the Brig Hendrick to the Consideration of Congress— The President thought it would be for the interest of the owners themselves to postpone it, at least till another session, but as Mr Buck insists upon their having their chance now, he requested me to prepare a message concerning it— I made a draft of a Message to inform Congress that the Journal of the Convention which formed the Constitution of the United States was published, and that a thousand copies were now deposited at the Department of State subject to the orders of Congress. I left the draft at the President’s and he promised to send in the Message next Monday— Dined with Mr Poletica the Russian Minister— A party of twenty-two men; chiefly diplomatic; with Mr Clay, Mr Brown of the Senate, Sergeant of the House; Mr Thompson, Secretary of the Navy, and the Attorney-General Wirt. Returning home this Evening I called at W. S. Smith’s for Mrs Adams and the children—who had dined there— W. D. Lewis was there.

18. VI: Visit from Mr Reid a member of the House of Representatives from Georgia; and also from Mr James Greenleaf proposing again to sell me some of his Squares in the City. He left me a list and description of them, with the respective prices at which he values them; and is to call again next week for my answer— I stopped at Mr Calhoun’s to enquire for his Report on the enquiry of the Committee of Foreign Relations; Mr Lowndes had called this Morning at my house to ask when I should be ready to answer his Letter. Calhoun desired me in order to make the information formal, to send him a note requesting it— And he agreed to meet at the President’s on Monday, at one O’Clock about the visiting question— I went to the Treasury Office and saw Mr Crawford; and afterwards Mr Wirt the Attorney General— Shewed them my draft of an answer to the question of the Committee— They made several observations upon it; suggesting modifications of several of the expressions in it— Mr Wirt thinks Congress will not approve the course recommended by the President of proceeding to execute the Treaty as if it had been ratified— Lowndes suggested a day or two since that the course of the Missouri Slave question might materially affect the disposition of the Northern people in regard to the acquisition of Florida— Every species of intrigue is working, and the result of their combinations is not easily to be seen— I was detained so late in these Conversations that I had a very short time at my Office, and none to call at the President’s— Mr Dana, member of the Senate from Connecticut came and had some Conversation with me concerning the abortive Treaty— This Evening, with Mrs Adams I called and took up Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith, and we attended the Ball at Mr Hyde de Neuville’s for the Duchess d’Angouleme’s Birth Day; instead of to-morrow; that being Sunday— Poletica, who had made preparation to celebrate the Emperor Alexander’s Birth-day, which is next Friday, the 24th. came to me in great perplexity having received a Card of invitation to dine that day with the President— I at first told him I would speak to the President about it, and had no doubt he would readily change his day; but I afterwards upon reflection advised Poletica himself to change his day, and keep the Emperor’s birth-day, the 25th. instead of the 24th. to which he very readily agreed— There was a fall of Snow this Evening; though not sufficient to cover the ground— I evaded the supper, and we came home about eleven— Clad this day first in full flannels.

19. VII: The day was in a great measure idled away— There was no religious service at the Capitol, Dr Allison the Chaplain to the House of Representatives being ill, and not able to procure a substitute— I loitered in the
morning till it was too late to go to Mr M’Cormick’s, and postponed it, intending to go to the Evening Service— But on returning the visits of several members of Congress, I was detained until it was again too late— I found at M’leods, General Alexander Smyth, Mr Silsbee and Mr Dowse— At QueensMr Tomlinson a member from Connecticut, and at Claxton’s Messrs. Edwards, Russ and Clagett with several others. At Dowsons I called to see Mr Freeman Walker, Senator from Georgia; but the servant called another Mr Walker, a Senator from Alabama— General Bloomfield was also there: and I met on the Hill, his nephew who arrived in the City yesterday— Mrs Adams being yet somewhat unwell kept house this day.

20. VI:Mr Kendrick the inventor came this morning to enquire if I had spoken to the President, about his machine for deepening rivers, which he is anxious to exhibit to him. I had forgotten it, but mentioned it this day, and the President agreed to see him the day after to-morrow at ten O’Clock— We had this day the Meeting at the President’s to consider the important question of etiquette in visiting— The members of the Senate it seems, not content with their rule that they will pay no first visit, but to the President, take it in dudgeon that the heads of Departments do not always pay the first visit to them— And it has come to the point of a complaint to the President, who inclined to think it would be well for the heads of Departments to indulge this humour of the Senators; and then, to avoid an invidious discrimination between the two Houses, to do the same thing by the Members of the House, and at the commencement of every Session of Congress to send round to all the lodging houses in the City about two hundred and thirty cards for each head of department. This however did not suit the views of any of us— We found however that we had no uniform practice, and each one was much disposed to adhere to his own. After discussing the matter about two hours, we could come to no other conclusion, than that each one should follow his own course— There are so many adverse pretensions that it is not possible to avoid giving offence to some—and it is equally ineffectual to defy or indulge the pretensions of the proud— The rule that I proposed was to separate entirely the official character from the practice of personal visiting—to pay no visits but for sake of friendship or acquaintance, and then without enquiring which is first or which is last and that their wives should practice the same— Mr Crawford and Mr Calhoun were willing to adopt this rule for themselves, and have indeed practiced upon it—but their wives have made it a point to visit first those of all members of Congress, and they would not alter that rule— My wife has followed the same rule for the Ladies that I have for the men, and as this has brought us into disgrace with all the members of Congress who have wives here, and with many others, Crawford whose policy it is in all things to cringe to members of Congress, because he has a steady eye upon the caucus, insists upon adhering to this system, though it gives offence to all the stranger Ladies who come here without happening to be the wives of Congressmen—and are therefore not honoured with Mrs Crawford’s visits— And thus it is that this paltry passion for precedence works along— I see no better course than that which I have deliberately followed because I thought it was right— Cardelli was here, this Evening.

21. VI:Mr James Greenleaf came this Morning for my answer to his proposals of selling me city Lots; but I have no humour for such a purchase at this time, and told him why. Mr W. D. Lewis was also here, and left with me a paper, to prove Levett Harris’s sale of the Vice Consulate of Archangel to Küsel— He also asked me, if he could see the paper which contained Harris’s charge against his brother John D. Lewis; which was at the Department of State; but it was among those taken away by Harris the other day— At the Office, Mr William Davis Robinson called at the Office— This person has been several years a State prisoner to the Spaniards, and some Months since made his escape from Cadix by a breach of his parole— He said he came to return his thanks to the Government for having interposed with that of Spain to obtain his release— Mr Buck the Consul general from Hamburg came to enquire concerning the case of the Cargo of the Brig Henrick— I told him the President would lay it before Congress in a Message— I Dined at the President’s with a company of twenty-five persons, Ladies and Gentlemen. The Heads of Departments and their Ladies, excepting Mr and Mrs Calhoun were there— The President of the Senate, Barbour, the Speaker of the House Clay, and several members of both houses— Clay told over again his story of the bottle of Kentucky wine that he once brought as a present to Mr Madison; and of Robert Smith’s saying it tasted of Whiskey
of his, Clay’s disposition at the time to cut off R. Smith’s head for the remark, and of its afterwards turning out that there really was whiskey in the wine: identically the same story which I heard him tell at the President’s table once before. I came home immediately after dinner, and J. Sergeant came with me. Mrs. Adams had a party of about a hundred persons at tea. Music; by some of the Ladies— Miss Vail sung.

22. VII: There was this morning an examination of the Scholars at Mr Ironside’s School, which I attended. Judge Anderson, the Comptroller of the Treasury, who hasthreesons at the school was also there— There were thirteen boys, of different standings and progress; among them, my Son Charles— The examination was barely passable; and the discipline very loose and disorderly. Mr Gaillard a member of the Senate, and Mr Earle of the House of Representatives, from South-Carolina, called at my Office, to request the appointment of the Pendleton Messenger, instead of the Winyaw Intelligencer, for printing the Laws in South Carolina; and I gave directions accordingly. I called at the President’s and left with him, a Letter which I have written to him upon the etiquette visiting affair— We spent the Evening at Mrs Forsyth’s. The Meigs family, and Mr and Mrs Lowndes were the only company. There was music, vocal and instrumental. Henry Meigs the member from New-York and his wife are both good singers— Mrs Adams also sung.

23. VI:30.Mr Edward Wyer, Consul at Hamburg, but having at present a leave of absence, called at my house this Morning having arrived in the City yesterday. At the Office Commodore Rogers came with a Mr Bruce, who applies for an appointment as Consul or Commercial Agent at Calcutta. I mentioned to him the objections of the British Government to admitting a person there with such an official character. He said the British Government could not prevent it, as it depended altogether upon the Government of the place under the Directors of the East-India Company— But as there is a Board of Controul, and a Superintendence of the British Cabinet, it could scarcely be expected that a foreign commercial agent should be received there against their will— Mr Parrott, the Senator from New-Hampshire came with Letters from two Citizens of that State, owners of a vessel and cargo seized at New-Orleans for having introduced into the United States two coloured persons, Slaves of Passengers in the vessel from Porto-Rico— There was already in the Office a Memorial from the Captain of the Vessel— This case gives me occasion to reflect upon the character and result of our Laws against the Slave-trade— Captain Rogers of the Steam-ship Savannah, brought me a Letter of strong recommendation from Mr Campbell at St. Petersburg. This vessel is the first which ever traversed the Ocean, with Steam Machinery— Since last May she has been from Savannah to Liverpool; thence up to the Baltic to St. Petersburg after touching Stockholm— Back to Copenhagen, Elseneur and Savannah; whence she has now come to this City. Theowners sent her to Russia in the expectation that the Emperor would purchase her; but having been disappointed in that hope, they have now sent her here to offer her to the Government of the United States; and Captain Rogers wishes to be employed in the Navy— Mr John Martin Baker came to ask for an appointment as one of the Agents to go to Africa, to take care of the negroes— The President called at the Office, and returned me the Letter I had left with him— He said the observations it contained had undoubtedly great weight; and as it principally concerned the members of the Senate, he thought it would be best that I should give a similiar explanation to the Vice-President, and ask him to communicate it to the members of the Senate, who have taken exception to my not paying them the first visit— That I should perhaps urge more particularly my own practice while I was a member of the Senate, and that I have never meant to assert any claim to first visits from any one— And he asked as a favour that I would omit the allusion to his daughter Mrs Hay— I shall do so; though Mrs Hay herself has been one of the principal causes of raising this senseless war of etiquette visiting— He told me that the person who had mentioned the subject to him was personally friendly to me, and that he had spoken of it, because it had excited some feeling among the Senators, and because uses were made of it, for political purposes, which he regretted to see— It was Mr Edwards the Senator from Illinois— I shall therefore write to the Vice-President, who arrived in the City last Evening— I dined with Mr Sanford, at his lodgings at Tennison’s Hotel, with a Company of fifteen or sixteen members of Congress— Walking home with Governor Edwards, I spoke to him of the etiquette question; but meeting immediately afterwards my Carriage, I parted from him, without having a full explanation— We spent the Evening at Coll. Bomford’s
with a company of perhaps 150 persons. My Son John arrived this afternoon from Cambridge; to pass the winter vacation with us— Edward Tayloe, came on with him— They left George, and young Calvert yesterday at Philadelphia; intending to come on from thence, this day— They left Boston last Saturday and came in the Mail-Stage as far as Philadelphia.

24. VI:15. Congress adjourned yesterday over till Monday next; after an unsuccessful attempt for an adjournment of ten days, by a joint Resolution— After several Months of almost uninterrupted drought, there was a fall of rain last Night and again several times this day— This Evening it turned to frost and hail— I was indebted to the weather, for being uninterrupted at the Office, except by a call from Forbes— I was at the President’s and took his directions upon various subjects— I mentioned to him that Mr Poletica, had engaged company to celebrate this day, being the Emperor Alexander’s Birth-day; but that by my advice had changed it until to-morrow, upon receiving the invitation to dine with the President this day— And observed if the President could take some occasion to let Poletica perceive that he recollected this was the Emperor’s birthday, it would be flattering to him, and I had no doubt would be gratifying to his Government; to whom he would certainly make it known— He said he would— I walked home in the rain— Mary Hellen spent the Evening at Mrs Forsyth’s; and Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith were here— I was in my chamber but so much overcome by drowsiness, that the time was quite wasted.

25. VI:30. Christmas day; and consequently no attendance at my Office— I employed it however not very profitably. Called at Mr Washington’s on the Capitol Hill, and returned the visit of Mr Ervin, Member of the House of Representatives from South-Carolina— I met there Mr Gaillard one of the Senators from the same State, and one of the Men of etiquette— He and Mr Brown of Louisiana have declined invitations to dine with us next Thursday, without assigning any reason, but in fact because I had not previously paid them visits of form— My Son George arrived by the Noon Stage from Baltimore—a day later than he had expected, the Steam-boat from Frenchtown, having got on shore and detained them too late to come by the Stages of yesterday from Baltimore— I dined at Mr. Poletica’s, with a company altogether diplomatic; excepting Commodore Decatur— All the members of the foreign Legations were there, excepting young Stoughton, whose only brother was killed last Monday in one of the Streets of New-York by a man named Goodwin, one of the Baltimore gang of Pirates, against whom he had been concerned in a Prosecution at Law— The dinner at Poletica’s was splendid; and like most of the company, in full dress— He asked me to toast the Emperor Alexander, which I did—adding, “in his life, may the prosperity of the future equal the glory of the past.” It was drank standing; in Champaign— After which Poletica gave in the same manner the President—[“]and may his future career be as honourable as it has been hitherto”—which he afterwards added he was perfectly assured it would be— He gave as a third toast, hinting to me that it was a toast which he could not decently avoid—“the allied Sovereigns of Europe.” The dinner was short, and from it, I walked over to Mr Frye’s, where my wife, and all the children had dined— And also Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith, with T. Boyd and Johnson Hellen— We spent the Evening there, and I walked home with George.

26. V:30. Attended public worship with Mrs Adamsand all the children, at the Hall of the House of Representatives, at the Capitol. Mr Post was the preacher, and took for his text the whole of the 84th. Psalm— He spoke without notes, and was fluent, but not eloquent— The house was thinly attended; after the Service was over I called at Davis’s Hotel to return E. Wyer’s visit— J. M. Forbes, and Dr Huntt called here— Mrs Adams and the children went, and passed the Evening at W. S. Smith’s.

27. VII:Mr Mark Langdon Hill, a Representative in Congress from Maine, and a member of the Committee of Commerce, called this morning at my house to enquire concerning the papers relative to the late negotiation with Great-Britain, upon the commercial intercourse between the United States, and the British Colonies in the West-Indies and in North-America. I had directed that all the papers should be
sent to the Committee. Mr Hill appeared to incline to a total prohibition of intercourse with the British Colonies and he shewed me Letters from Mr William King, and William Gray of Boston expressing the same opinion— He was very desirous of knowing what were the views of the Executive Government on this subject; and I promised to mention it to the President— I had much conversation with Mr Hill upon various topics; particularly upon our commercial relations with Russia, and the political transactions while I was there— He also shewed me a Letter from Mr Jefferson to the late John Langdon of New-Hampshire, written in the year 1810. full of his political Shandyism; a mixture of profound and sagacious observation with strong prejudices, and irritated passions. It is a sort of epitome of his political opinions and feelings— Jefferson is one of the Great Men whom this Country has produced, one of the men, who has contributed largely to the formation of our national character—to much that is good, and to not a little that is evil in our sentiments and manners— His Declaration of Independence is an abridged Alcoran of political doctrine; laying open the first foundations of civil Society—but he does not appear to have been aware that is also laid open a precipice into which the Slave-holding Planters of his Country, sooner or later must fall— With the Declaration of Independence on their lips and the merciless Scourge of Slavery in their hands, a more flagrant image of human inconsistency can scarcely be conceived than one of our Southern Slave-holding Republicans— Jefferson has been himself all his life a Slave-holder; but he has published opinions so blasting to the very existence of Slavery, that however creditable they may be to his candour and humanity, they speak not much for his prudence or his forecast as a Virginian Planter— The seeds of the Declaration of Independence are yet maturing— The Harvest will be what West the Painter calls the terrible sublime— Mr Woodbridge the Delegate from the Michigan Territory; and who is also the Secretary of the Territory, came with Daniel Pope Cook, Member from Illinois. Woodbridge said he had heard, that application had been made to the President, for the appointment of Secretary to the Territory, as if it were vacated by his election as a Delegate— But that this had not been his understanding, nor the intention of those who had elected him— They did not consider the Offices of Secretary and Delegate for the Territory as incompatible; and if they should be thought so by Congress of the President, he should resign his seat, and wish to be considered a candidate for re-appointment as Secretary— I said I would mention it to the President, but I had not heard of any application for the Office— Cook told me that the District Attorney in Illinois held an Office under the State, which by the Constitution of the State was incompatible with it— Which he wished might be known to the President— I promised to mention it, but said I thought the President would be of opinion that as the incompatibility was by the State Constitution, it would be for the State Authorities to apply the remedy— He said he had supposed that this would be the President’s conclusion; but as the fact was that the Governor of the State would not carry the Constitutional prohibition into effect, he had thought it best that the Circumstance should be communicated to the President— The Vice-President, Tompkins, called and returned my visit. I spoke to him on the affair of etiquette visiting; and told him I should write him a private Letter concerning it, and should request him to shew it to the members of the Senate, which he said he would. He observed that Mr Thompson, the Secretary of the Navy had spoken of it to him; that he thought our principle was correct, but that some of the Southern Members, and especially Mr Brown of Louisiana and Mr Gaillard of South-Carolina, were peculiarly tenacious in their claim to a first visit. And the principle upon which they rested their claim was that the Senate being by their concurrence to appointments a component part of the Supreme Executive, therefore Senators ought to be first visited by Heads of Departments— I said I thought the conclusion not logical; and if it was it would require that Senators at home should visit every member of the Legislatures by which they were chosen, a practice which certainly existed no where. He said it would apply still more strongly to the members of the Council of Appointment in New-York, who not only voted on appointments but had a right of nominating, concurrent with the Governor— He says the same question of the first visit is made with these Senators by Members of the House of Representatives, and that there are many Members of the House with whom Mr Brown will not associate, because they refuse to pay him a first visit— So that this question of
etiquette visiting is becoming quite an affair of State— The calls of so many persons at my house made me very late this Morning at my Office; where I had a long visit from Captain O’Brien; who came for a Passport to the fifth Auditor, Pleasonton for a budget of old claims. I called at the President’s; but he had rode out— Evening in my chamber, writing. Cardelli below.

28. VI:30. The morning was occupied with my Journal— Pleasonton called at my Office, and I gave him Captain O’Brien’s and Nathaniel Cutting’s papers with the request that if he could consistently with the established principles in the Settlement of Accounts admit any part of their claims he would do so— It is a severe and painful duty to reject the claims of men who have served the public upon inadequate compensations; grown old and poor in the service, and advance claims which have a colour of Justice, but are not sanctioned by Law— Mr Roberts Senator from Pennsylvania, came to the Office, with Mr Raguet a member of the Senate of the State of Pennsylvania— The Legislature of that State have adjourned for ten days, on account of the Christmas Holidays, and Mr Raguet has taken the opportunity to pay a visit here— I called at the President’s, and left with him a despatch about the Slave-trade received from R. Rush. I spoke to him of the questions suggested to me yesterday by Mr Hill, Mr Woodbridge, and Mr Cook— He directed a meeting of the members of the Administration, the day after to-morrow at twelve O’Clock; to take into consideration the trade with the British West-India Colonies— He had received no application for the appointment of Secretary to the Territory of Michigan, and he thought the State of Illinois must be left to carry into effect it own constitutional prohibitions— He said there had been a complaint made to him that the Offices of District Attorney, and Receiver of Public Monies, had been united in one person in Alabama; which would require consideration— Mrs Adams had this Evening her weekly tea-party— The fourth in succession— There were about a hundred persons present; and the companies have been with a few exceptions different, every one of those Evenings.

29. VII: I called this Morning at Miss Queen’s on Doctor Thomas Sewall, a young man, who brought me last spring a Letter of recommendation from Judge David Sewall, and who has now come to reside here, and practice his profession. At the Office Mr Pleasonton came and introduced Coll. M’Lean, Collector of the Port of Wilmington, Delaware, and an old Officer of our revolutionary War— He had much to say on the Spirit of the Times in 1775 and 1776— Mr Jeremiah Nelson, member of Congress from the Northern Essex District, Massachusetts, brought a memorial from several merchants at Boston, to the President, containing a list of depredations committed by the piratical privateers— Mr F. Walker the Senator from Georgia, came with two old certificates of Yazoo Stock, to enquire whether it appeared by the papers of the Commissioners deposited in the Office of the Department of State whether provision had been made for them in the Settlement. I dined with George, at Mr Hyde de Neuville’s, and in the Evening attended the Drawing Room at the President’s— Mrs Adams was confined the whole day to her bed; and John though invited to dine at Mr de Neuville’s made an excuse not to go. The drawing room was over before half past nine O’Clock.

30. VI:45. A Snow-Storm, the severest, with one exception that I ever witnessed in this place; which continued through the whole day, prevented my attendance at my Office— The time at home was employed, not so profitably as it should have been— We had company to dinner— Vice-President Tompkins— Mr Clay, Speaker of the House of Representatives— Mr Thompson Secretary of the Navy— Mr Wirt, Attorney General— Messrs.Barbour, Dickerson, Edwards, Sanford and Walker of Georgia, Members of the Senate, and Lowndes, Mason, Smith of Maryland and Trimble, of the House of Representatives— There had been invited Messrs.Brown and Gaillard of the Senate, who answered that they sincerely regretted they could not dine with us, but whose reason for declining was the first visit etiquette affair— Otis, who declined having very recently lost a daughter— Calhoun, Crawford, Pinckney, Macon, and Rhea, who accepted, but were prevented from coming by the Storm; and all except Rhea, sent excuses this day.— The party was agreeable as this violence of the weather would admit; but the company all went away before nine in the Evening— I had several sharp admonitions of the return of old rhumatisms.

31. VII: It was the coldest Night we have had this Season— Fahrenheit’s Thermometer when I went to bed last Night, and when I rose this Morning was at 18. And the cold this morning was my excuse for rising late, and for doing
very little after I rose. At the Office, Major Roberdeau called and shewed me a foot measure of copper, which he had made for a standard, with several other scales upon it for the purposes of topographical mensuration— I asked him if he knew where Troughton’s scale of 82 inches, which was procured by Hassler in England now is— He told me that it was here; that he would enquire for it; and let me know where it is to be seen— Pleasonton came to ask for one of the Rooms belonging to the Department of State— I desired him and Mr Young to see that the Account of the Contingent expences of the Department should be settled at the close of the present year— There are different Clerks in the Treasury Department who have different modes of stating Accounts; and one of them charges large overdrafts upon the Department of State, while another presents them, with a balance yet unexpended— I called at the President’s, with several papers for his directions, and to apologize for not having attended yesterday at the Cabinet Meeting; owing to the Snow-Storm; and my rheumatic symptoms— The President mentioned several unpleasant disorderly occurrences at the Drawing-Rooms, and appeared to regret that he had not laid them aside altogether— One was of a Clerk in the Navy Department named Sherburne who having really no right to attend the Drawing Room, had not only come himself, but brought another person still more improper with him, who had abused and ill-treated the Servants in the house. Another was an insolent attempt of an English servant of Antrobus’s to force his way into the Hall of entrance— Of these petty untoward incidents there will always be more or less, where large parties of company assemble— I rather disuaded the President from making any new regulations, to exclude any one from the Drawing Rooms; but advised him if it should be found necessary to employ one or two Constables to keep order in the yard— Cardelli gave a lesson to the Children this Evening; and I spent it in my chamber, writing.

Day. Congress having been in Session the greater part of this Month, my occupations, and the distribution of my time have been in some measure influenced by them— As the longest nights, and the severity of Winter have come on, my rising hour has grown later— Dining and Evening parties are also frequently recurring, and absorb many precious hours— My personal acquaintance among the members of Congress, becomes more extensive, and more burdensome. Visiting has taken up more time— The necessary consequence of which is that little real and important business is effected— The prolixity of the Diary is yet unabated.

And thus closes another year upon the irredeemable ages of time past. In the political annals of my life, it has been distinguished as a year of great promise and great disappointment— The Florida Treaty if ratified would have been an important event— It has proved a magnificent abortion— Events of a painful nature have occurred in my private and domestic relations— Nothing has prospered in the course of the year; but my life and health, and the nearest and dearest of my friends and relatives have been preserved— My worldly concerns though not favoured with any instances of success have suffered no severe shock; and innumerable mercies have called for numberless streams of gratitude from my heart to the Fountain of all Good— With unbounded thankfulness for the past, let me unite fervent supplications for the future. May the God of Mercy and of Consolation, still guide my steps, support my weakness; forgive my errors, and preserve me from crimes— May the blessings of an approving Conscience be mine, through the remnant of my days and at my latest breath; and may they be deserved and enjoyed by my children after me— May all my Passions be under the controul of my Judgment, and may my soul be elevated equally above the miseries and the enjoyments of this World. Prepare me Heavenly father for all the allotments of Earth; and purify me for all the felicities of Heaven.
